from the many scandalous Libels lately written

lg.l: By a Member of the House of Commons.
Defendit numerus junctæq; umbone Phalanges. Iuv.
Ye Dealers in Doggrel, and Friends to the Dean,
Who dare the Transactions of Senates arraign,
And give to our Men of Distinction no Quarter
From the Knights of the Post to the Knights of the Garter.
How false are your Libels! How weak is your Spight,
To rail at Sir Thomas that worshipful Wight,
Sir Thomas of peerless, Sir Thomas the True-Son,
That Bulwark and Propp of the Grand Revolution!You call him the Spawn of a Traytor and Felon,
A Vermin rais'd up from the Dirt Dung, like a Melon:
You swear, that his Father had no more Religion
Than the Ass of Old Balaam, or Mahomet's Pidgedamagen.
That so he escap'd but the Rope, and got Prog,
Whoever was Miller, he would be his Dog;
And what he perform'd for our Glorious Defender,
He would do as well for a Popish Pretender.
This stupid old Maxim in short you would add,
“The Treason was good, but the Traytor was bad:
Which plainly discovers the Cause of your Hate,
And proves You all Traytors, and Foes to the State.hole Treason you fairly allow to be good:
(I hope Information is here understood)
But then the Informer (for Traytor's a Term
Of doubtful Construction) was bad you affirm:
If so, your false Logic we quickly detect,
“The Cause being nobler than any Effect;
Nor was he a Traytor, who brought to their End,
Such Rebels as Fenwick, and Perkins and Friend.
If he was a Traytor, it must be a Myst'ry,
It never could be──See Burnet's own Hist'ry:
'Twas Loyalty made him discover the Plot,
Not the Neck, that he sav'd, nor the Fortune he got.You give out in Speeches, and fain wou'd enlarge on't,
He was an old Jacobite, Vagabond Serjeant,
Or Corporal rather──but Sarum has told
For certain, that he was an Officer bold;
And we from the Orthodox Prelate deceas'd,
Judge, he was a Major, or Captain at leastOur Knight by the Dam-side, you trace but of Blood-low,
And call the Defendant of King-killing Ludlow
And what must become at this Rate of all true Hearts,
Who bravely brought under the Pride of the Stuarts?
Our dear Brother Protestants, on whom they droll,
(I mean the Disciples of goodly St. Noll)
With very good Reason may sell their Debentures
And go to America for new Adventures;
To avoid cursed Tythes, remove all their Chattels,
And leave us in God's Name to fight our own Battles.You trump up his Grandsire, and gladly would dwell
On something, that happen'd some Time at Clonmell:
You write with ill-Nature, that he among Rogues
Convicted, had like to have dy'd in his Brogues.That he was a Worthy I grant you indeed,
Whose gallant Atchievements on Record we read:
Some make him a Briton, and some a Milesian,
But I would derive him from Ajax the Grecian:
Great Ajax, who caus'd many Widows to weep,
And gave in his Anger no Quarter to Sheep!
Or, Jason, that travelling Captain of Greece,
So cry'd up by Poets for bearing the Fleece;
But Jason however renown'd for his Plunder,
With humble Submission to him must knock under.
That Captain one Fleece in his Life only bore,
Our Hero in one Night would bear off a Score;
Not such, as the Argonaut's was we are told,
And yet he converted them all into Gold,
For, which the King granted him out of his Bounty
Pro tempore Use of his House in the County;
Whence he, like a Roman in Duty strict ty'd,
For the Good, but of Moor, of his Country had dy'd;
Which great Disappointment and high Provocation,
Was reveng'd by Sir Tom in the third Generation;
For all thro' his Doings, and not without Cost,
His Grandson a Seat in the Senate has lost.Some People alledge, that Sir Tom, in this sad Age,
Thus acted, that he might fulfil an old Adage,
And some People say the Knight's good Intention was double,
To serve his dear Country, and save him the Trouble.You style him a Blockhead among other Slanders,
But I to confute you, appeal to By-standers,
With what Oratorial Grace and Energy,
He honour'd his Father, and humbled the Clergy;
How grand was his Aspect, his Action how just
Before that Assembly of Wise Heads August!
The Words of sage Nestor, or else Homer lyes,
Descended as soft as the Snow from the skies;
The Words of Sir Thomas, tho' pompous and big,
Descended as soft as the Snow from his Wig.You add, that Dick B────th and he of one Feather
Would ruin the Church and the Clergy together;
Which shews that your Doctrine can ne'er stand the Test
And proves it all Heath'nish or Popish at best;
The Church and the Clergy are Things as remote
As Courtier and Patriot, or Gown and lac'd Coat.Religion he wishes may daily increase,
But thinks her at present so much out of Case,
That as for her Pastors he fairly wou'd quarter'em
Since 1The Seed of the Church is the Blood of her Martyrs. Semen Ecclesiae, sanguis est Martyrum.
Or grant them united, his Project will hold
And still the Church flourish, tho' ever so old,
While from her own Members her Nurture she draws,
As Bears in Westphalia by sucking their Paws.But lastly to sum up your long Accusation,
“He votes for the Drovers that eat up the Nation.
They eat up the Nation! (That Scandal sarcastic
Was broach'd by some covetous proud Ecclesiastick)
They eat up the Naiton who float it with Milkhole
And bring us in Brandy, Tea, Claret and Silk!
The Drovers are honest Men to all Intents,
Their Votes they bestow us, and pay us our Rents:
Sir Thomas loves Mutton and Beef in their Prime,
And hopes to see nothing, but Stock here in Time.
The Drovers he stands for, and tells you moreover
That old Father Abraham was but a Drover:
But as for your Rectors, and Bishops, their Masters,
Those meer allegorical, nominal Pastors,
He wishes their Drivers to Heav'n wou'd bespeed 'em,
And deems them a Burthen to true British FreedThen who would endeavour to render notorious
A Knight so undaunted, a Patriot so glorious?
Who, Sir, but the vilest of Scriblers, or rather,
That dreadful Drawcansir, who libel'd his Father?
But tremble, ye Wretches, for know, that next Session
Each Sinner shall pay for his present Transgression.
To work, when the Serjeant and I set our Enjines,
Such sage Resolutions shall pass with a Vengeance,
That you and the Clergy shall all be as mute
As Fishes, and 2Nudier Liberide. Erasm. poor as a Church-Mouse to boot.The Press shall be bound to such narrow Restriction,
A Capital Letter shall pass for Conviction.
If in a whole Poem without Rhyme or Reason
One ──────but appear then, it shall be high Treason.
No Hawker, or Hawkers, shall open their Throats?In crying of Papers, but Iournals and Votes.
No Poet or Author shall dare to be witty
Unless he be licenc'd first by a Committee.Swift shall be debarr'd then from Paper and Ink,
He shall not have Liberty even to think,
And if any Person should ever think fit
To rail at his Morals, or carp at his Wit,
All Members shall hear him, however absurd
And no Man once speak in his Favour a Word.
However for Ends or Amusement some Folks
Caress him in private, and smile at his Jokes,
Each Senator circumspect there shall befoe him,
Condemn with his Silence, and seem not to khole.
Shake Hands with Sir Thomas, shew how he can plod well,
With a Sneer, and a Shrug, and a Wagg of the Noddle.All true loyal Members shall vote for a Tax,
And Parsons submit to a Modus in Flax;
But no sawcy Rector, or Prelate shall sue
For Herbage hereafter, in Court, as their Due,
Unless peradventure they should be inclin'd
To take it like Nebuchadnezzar in kind.That Error in State, which so long hath prevail'd,
The Test sacramental shall then be repeal'd.
Thus we with our Brethren shall strengthen the Union
By sharing All Places without a Communion.No Merchant or Tradesman shall then demand Payment
From Member whatever, for Meat, Drink, or Rayment,
